text:
I was never one of those kids who had a lot of friends or enjoyed being around people. I always felt like the odd one out. Growing up, I was never outgoing, and I preferred my own company. I kept to myself, and even when I was around other people, I was the one who stayed quiet and listened.

My parents were kind and loving, but I still felt disconnected from them. I was never able to express myself in a way that they could understand, so I kept my thoughts and feelings to myself. I was an introverted kid, and I never really had much to say.

School was a place where I could hide away from the social pressures that came with being around other kids my age. I was never good at making friends or fitting in with the popular crowd, so I spent a lot of my time alone. I was good at my studies, so I threw myself into my schoolwork and tried to stay out of the spotlight.

I was always aware of how different I was from the other kids, and I was never quite sure how to fit in. I was an outsider, and I often felt like an outcast. My lack of social skills and my introverted nature made me stand out from the crowd. I was often the target of jokes and bullying, which made me even more reclusive.

My parents did their best to support me, but it never seemed to be enough. I was always the one who was left out when the other kids were having fun, and I felt like I didn’t belong. I was always the one who was standing in the corner, watching everyone else.

I had one friend growing up, a girl who was also an outsider like me. We had similar interests, and we often spent time together, but even she eventually moved away and I was all alone again.

I was never able to express my feelings in a way that made sense to other people, so I often felt misunderstood. I was never able to open up to anyone about my thoughts and emotions, so I kept them bottled up inside.

I was an introverted, antagonistic, unconscientious, emotionally stable, and closed to experience kid who was never quite sure how to fit in. I was always the one who was standing in the corner, watching everyone else and feeling like I didn’t belong. I kept to myself, and I often felt like an outcast. 

I had my studies to keep me occupied, which was enough to get me through the day, but I was still lonely and isolated. I was never able to break out of my shell, and I was never able to connect with other people in a meaningful way.

Growing up was a challenge, but I made it through. I may not have been the most popular kid in school, but I was content with who I was. I learned to be comfortable in my own skin and to accept myself for who I am.
prompt:
